description: Alan Turing publishes his foundational paper introducing the concept of the Turing machine, establishing the theoretical basis for computation and what would later become artificial intelligence.
Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts publish "A Logical Calculus of Ideas Immanent in Nervous Activity," introducing the first mathematical model of artificial neurons.
Vannevar Bush describes the Memex in "As We May Think," envisioning a device that could store and retrieve information, prefiguring concepts of artificial intelligence and hypertext.
Claude Shannon publishes "A Mathematical Theory of Communication," laying the foundation for information theory and digital communication, crucial for AI development.
Donald Hebb introduces Hebbian learning in "The Organization of Behavior," proposing that neural pathways are strengthened through repeated use, influencing later neural network models.
AI systems based on logic and rules; focused on manipulating symbols and reasoning explicitly.
Alan Turing proposed the Turing Test as a measure of machine intelligence, suggesting that if a machine could converse indistinguishably from a human, it could be considered intelligent.
Marvin Minsky and Dean Edmonds build the first neural network machine, SNARC (Stochastic Neural Analog Reinforcement Calculator), using 3,000 vacuum tubes to simulate 40 neurons.
Arthur Samuel creates a checkers-playing program for IBM, one of the first programs to demonstrate machine learning by improving its performance through self-play.
Allen Newell and Herbert Simon develop the Logic Theorist, often considered the first AI program, which could prove mathematical theorems using symbolic reasoning.
The founding moment of AI as a field; organized by John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Nathaniel Rochester, and Claude Shannon.
Frank Rosenblatt invents the Perceptron, the first artificial neural network capable of learning, marking the beginning of modern neural network research.
John McCarthy develops LISP, a programming language that becomes fundamental to AI research due to its ability to manipulate symbolic information and support recursive functions.
Newell and Simon create GPS, an early AI program designed to solve a wide range of problems using means-ends analysis, demonstrating general problem-solving capabilities.
The first industrial robot, Unimate, begins work at General Motors, marking the beginning of practical robotics applications in manufacturing.
Bernard Widrow and Ted Hoff develop ADALINE, an early adaptive neural network that could learn and adjust its weights, advancing neural network capabilities.
Daniel Bobrow creates STUDENT, one of the first natural language processing programs capable of solving algebra word problems by understanding English text.
Joseph Weizenbaum created ELIZA, an early natural language processing program that simulated conversation, marking the beginning of human-computer interaction research.
SRI International begins development of Shakey, the first mobile robot to reason about its actions, integrating AI with robotics and computer vision.
Stanley Kubrick's film introduces HAL 9000, popularizing the concept of artificial intelligence in popular culture and raising questions about AI consciousness and ethics.

event: Perceptrons Book by Minsky and Papert
description: Marvin Minsky and Seymour Papert publish "Perceptrons," highlighting the limitations of single-layer neural networks and contributing to the first AI winter.
Alain Colmerauer develops Prolog, a logic programming language that becomes important for AI applications, particularly in expert systems and natural language processing.
Japan's Waseda University creates WABOT-1, the first full-scale humanoid robot capable of walking, grasping objects, and rudimentary conversation.
Sir James Lighthill publishes a critical report on AI research in the UK, leading to significant cuts in AI funding and contributing to the first AI winter.
Period of reduced funding and interest due to unmet expectations and lack of progress in GOFAI.
John Holland publishes "Adaptation in Natural and Artificial Systems," introducing genetic algorithms as a method for optimization and machine learning inspired by evolution.
Edward Shortliffe develops MYCIN at Stanford, an expert system for diagnosing bacterial infections, demonstrating practical applications of AI in medicine.
The Stanford Cart successfully navigates a chair-filled room autonomously, demonstrating advances in computer vision and mobile robotics.
Proposed by John Searle; a philosophical critique of the notion that symbol manipulation equals understanding or consciousness.
Japan launches an ambitious 10-year project to develop computers using AI and parallel processing, spurring international competition in AI research.
John Hopfield introduces Hopfield networks, a form of recurrent artificial neural network that can serve as associative memory systems.
Apple creates the Knowledge Navigator concept video, envisioning AI assistants and tablets, influencing future development of personal AI technologies.
Douglas Lenat begins the Cyc project, an ambitious attempt to create a comprehensive ontology and knowledge base of everyday common sense knowledge.
Terrence Sejnowski and Charles Rosenberg create NetTalk, a neural network that learns to pronounce English text, demonstrating the power of connectionist approaches.
David Rumelhart, Geoffrey Hinton, and Ronald Williams popularized the use of backpropagation for training neural networks, making deep learning feasible.
The market for specialized LISP machines collapses as general-purpose computers become more powerful, contributing to the second AI winter.
Second period of reduced funding and interest due to collapse in the market for specialized AI hardware.
Judea Pearl publishes work on probabilistic reasoning and Bayesian networks, providing mathematical foundations for dealing with uncertainty in AI.
Yann LeCun develops convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for handwritten digit recognition, laying groundwork for modern computer vision.
Rodney Brooks introduces the subsumption architecture and behavior-based robotics, emphasizing embodied intelligence and real-world interaction.
Richard Sutton and Andrew Barto publish foundational work on reinforcement learning, formalizing how agents can learn through trial and error.
Vladimir Vapnik and Alexey Chervonenkis introduced SVMs, a powerful algorithm for classification and regression, marking a shift towards more robust machine learning models.
Vernor Vinge popularizes the concept of technological singularity, predicting that superhuman intelligence will fundamentally change civilization.
The first full-text web search engine launches, using early AI techniques for information retrieval and ranking, presaging modern search AI.
Leo Breiman develops Random Forest, an ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees, becoming widely used in machine learning applications.
Honda begins development of ASIMO, an advanced humanoid robot that would become one of the most sophisticated walking robots of its era.
IBM's Deep Blue becomes the first computer to defeat a world chess champion (Garry Kasparov) in a match, marking a milestone in AI game-playing capabilities.
Sepp Hochreiter and Jürgen Schmidhuber introduced LSTMs, a type of RNN that overcomes the vanishing gradient problem, making learning over long sequences possible.
A benchmark dataset of handwritten digits that became a standard for testing image classification algorithms.
MIT develops Cog, a humanoid robot designed to learn and develop like a human child, advancing research in developmental robotics and AI.
Sony releases AIBO, an entertainment robot dog with AI capabilities, bringing AI-powered robotics into consumer homes for the first time.

After early excitement around expert systems and neural networks in the 1990s, AI progress slowed. Funding declined as machine learning models underperformed expectations, and neural networks were seen as outdated.
Wikipedia is founded, creating one of the largest collaborative knowledge bases that would later become crucial training data for AI language models.
iRobot releases the Roomba, the first successful autonomous cleaning robot for consumers, demonstrating practical AI applications in everyday life.
The completion of the Human Genome Project creates vast biological datasets that drive development of AI applications in bioinformatics and genomics.

DARPA's first autonomous vehicle challenge pushes development of self-driving car technology, spurring advances in AI for transportation. Stanley, an autonomous car, won the DARPA Grand Challenge, catalyzing self-driving car development.
Geoffrey Hinton et al. introduced Deep Belief Networks, sparking renewed interest in training deeper neural networks, leading to the modern deep learning boom.
NVIDIA launched CUDA, a programming model that made it much easier for researchers to write GPU-accelerated code in C/C++, a major turning point for deep learning.
Google publishes papers on MapReduce and BigTable, enabling large-scale data processing that becomes essential for training large AI models.
A large-scale image dataset that provided the foundation for breakthroughs in computer vision.
Microsoft releases Kinect, bringing computer vision and gesture recognition to consumer gaming, demonstrating practical applications of AI perception technologies.
IBM's Watson defeats human champions in Jeopardy!, demonstrating advances in natural language processing and question-answering systems.
A deep CNN by Alex Krizhevsky et al. that dramatically improved image classification performance on ImageNet, marking the mainstream success of deep learning with GPU-powered models.
Google releases Word2Vec, a neural network model that creates meaningful vector representations of words, revolutionizing natural language processing.
Ian Goodfellow et al. introduced Generative Adversarial Networks, a new class of generative models that could create high-quality images, text, and other media.
Amazon releases Alexa, bringing voice-controlled AI assistants into homes and demonstrating practical applications of speech recognition and natural language understanding.
Microsoft Research introduces ResNet (Residual Networks), enabling the training of much deeper neural networks and advancing computer vision capabilities.
DeepMind's AlphaGo defeats world Go champion Lee Sedol, demonstrating AI's ability to master complex strategic games previously thought impossible for computers.
Famous paper by Vaswani et al. introduced the Transformer architecture, revolutionizing NLP with its attention mechanisms for parallel data processing.
Transformers became dominant in NLP, surpassing RNNs for tasks like translation and summarization.
OpenAI released the first Generative Pre-trained Transformer, showing strong zero-shot performance in a variety of NLP tasks.
Google releases BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), setting new standards for natural language understanding tasks.
A significantly larger version of GPT-1; initially withheld due to concerns about misuse, it showcased impressive text generation capabilities.
DeepMind's AlphaStar achieves Grandmaster level in StarCraft II, demonstrating AI's ability to handle complex real-time strategy games.
OpenAI released GPT-3, a 175 billion parameter model that set a new standard for general-purpose text generation, enabling a wide range of applications.
OpenAI presented DALL-E, showing how transformer models could generate images from text prompts, opening a new era of creative AI.
IBM Watson for Oncology was used to assist oncologists in diagnosing and recommending treatments, marking the beginning of AI's widespread integration in healthcare.
DeepMind's AlphaFold achieves breakthrough accuracy in predicting protein structures, revolutionizing biological research and drug discovery.
GitHub and OpenAI launch Copilot, an AI-powered coding assistant that helps developers write code, demonstrating practical AI applications in software development.
Google releases PaLM (Pathways Language Model), demonstrating improved reasoning and mathematical capabilities in large language models.
OpenAI launched ChatGPT, a conversational AI based on GPT-3.5, marking a major milestone in public interaction with large language models.
Rise of AI ethics boards reflecting increased awareness of AI's potential biases, ethical challenges, and its role in issues like discrimination and surveillance.
Stability AI releases Stable Diffusion as open source, democratizing access to high-quality AI image generation and spurring widespread adoption.
OpenAI releases DALL-E 2 with significantly improved image quality and resolution, advancing the field of AI-generated art and imagery.
A multimodal model with improved reasoning, factuality, and image understanding, expanding the capabilities of AI in handling text and images together.
Google launches Bard, its conversational AI to compete with ChatGPT, marking increased competition in the large language model space.
Auto-GPT and similar autonomous AI agents emerge, capable of breaking down tasks and executing them independently with minimal human oversight.
Increased focus on AI safety, alignment, and the development of Constitutional AI methods to ensure AI systems behave according to human values.
Multiple open-weight models (e.g., Mistral, Mixtral, Phi-2) gained traction for high performance in compact architectures.
Google DeepMind launched Gemini 1, a family of powerful multimodal models rivaling GPT-4.
Anthropic released Claude 3 models with significant improvements in reasoning, language fluency, and safety, used in AI coding tools like Cursor and Lovable.
DeepSeek, a prominent AI lab, released large-scale open-source LLMs and code models, increasing transparency and competition in the LLM space.
OpenAI demonstrates Sora, a text-to-video generation model capable of creating realistic videos from text prompts, advancing multimodal AI capabilities.
AI models increasingly contribute to scientific breakthroughs, from drug discovery to materials science, demonstrating AI's role in accelerating research.
Major models increasingly support multimodal input/output, including video understanding and generation capabilities.
Governments worldwide implement comprehensive AI regulation frameworks, balancing innovation with safety and ethical considerations.
The first viable quantum AI models are developed, harnessing quantum computing to solve complex optimization problems previously unsolvable by classical AI.
The first systems approaching AGI capabilities emerge, demonstrating human-level performance across a wide range of cognitive tasks.
Seamless AI-human collaboration becomes the norm in most knowledge work, with AI serving as intelligent co-workers rather than replacement tools.
The question of AI consciousness becomes a central philosophical and legal issue as AI systems demonstrate increasingly sophisticated self-awareness and reasoning.
